text: According to Duden, approximately 46% of German nouns are feminine, 34% are masculine and 20% are neuter.
All German nouns formed by adding the suffix -ung to a verb are feminine.
Most nouns with an unstressed ending -e are feminine. Careful: There are exceptions for masculine and neutral!
Most names of fruits in German are feminine.
Most names of flowers in German are feminine.
Most names of trees in German are feminine.
Cardinal numbers in German are feminine.
Feminine occupations add the ending -in and always stay feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -ei are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -heit are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -ie are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -ik are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -ion are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -it√§t are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -keit are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -schaft are feminine.
Most nouns with the ending -ur are feminine.
Over 65% of one-syllable words in German are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ant are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ent are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ich are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ismus are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ist are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ling are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -or are masculine.
Occupations with the ending -er or -eur are masculine.
Names of seasons are masculine.
Names of months are masculine.
Names of days are masculine.
Map and compass directions are masculine.
Names of cars and trains are masculine.
Most currencies are masculine.
All diminutive German nouns with the ending -chen or -lein are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -ma are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -ment are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -nis are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -tel are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -tum are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -um are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -ig (except for numbers) are masculine.
Most nouns with the ending -ast are masculine.
Names of colors in German are neuter.
Most metals and units in German are neuter.
Nouns which stem from verb infinitives in -en are neuter.
Most nouns with the prefix Ge- are neuter.
Most nouns with the ending -enz are feminine.
